document.text: Wed.. Dec. 4 Judge D. Carl ton Mayes of the Fourth Judici ary Circuit, presided over the County Circuit Court in the ab sence of Judge Joel Flood, a pat ient at Virginia Baptist Hospital in Lynchburg. The announcement of the tem porary appointment came last week from the State Supreme Courts of Appeals in Richmond The announcement was released by Claude W. Smith, clerk of the Fifth Judiciary Circuit Court is Appcmattox.

document.text: I g e George F. Abbitt, Jr., administers the oath i e newly appointed clerk of Appomattox County, ._ Gordon, in a brief ceremony Saturday morning office. Mrs. Gordon will fill out the unexpired a n clerk Claude W. Smith who retired July 15, t h e county in the clerks office since 1908. Mrs. , e e n serving as deputy clerk for 14 years.

document.text: C. Lewis McDearmon, busi nessman and town councilman, was acquited Saturday by a 12 member Jury, 11 men and one woman, on a charge of murder in the slaying of Morton Lewis Ferguson. The jury retired from the courtroom at 350 p.m. Sat. and jtoturiied.ALIi9.p.nf. with the verdict of not guilty. Court Clerk Claude W. Smith read the ver dict in front of an estimated 300 persons crowded into the court room and. adjoining offices. McDearmons trail began at 10 p.m, Thursday, Jan. 3, with an overnight recess on Thursday and Friday nights. The Jury was detained Friday night at a Lynch burg hotel by order of Judge Joel Hood. McDearmon had pleaded not guilty and did not testify during the trial.

document.text: The financial statement o Appomattox County recently completed by Claude W- Smith county Clerk, shows the dis bursements for county expen ses from July 1, 1927, to June 30, 1930 to be approximately 18,000 leaving a balance of a little over  11,000 in the treas ury. Total receipts for the year ending last June were 29,374. 28, of which 8,480,99 was a balance carried over from the year before. Receipts for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1929 totaled only 27,674.68, Expenditures for pauper ca ses and poor house expense were practically the same thit year as last Less money vn. spent for poor house cases anc more for aid outside the poo house, but there is little diff erence in the total. The school appropriation made for county funds to ena ble the schools to complete tht term was cut this year to less than half the amount appropri ated the year before- In 1928 29 the supervisors appropriat ed 2,600 and in 1929-30, on ly  1,200 was appropriated. Expenses for maintaining h clerks office, court house anc jail this year were 623.34 while for-last year they amoun ed to 1,247.26. However, in surance on the three building, was included in the expense., of last year. . Lunacy and feeble-mindec commissions this year cost th county 144.80. while las year they cost 111.10 Ther was a cut of about 300 in th salaries paid county officer, this year. The total salarie paid was 5,577.20, as compar ed with 5,863.70 of last year The county appropriated S 241.54 last year for roads an 3,00815 this year The amour, allowed for stock and fowls k, led by dogs was 135-54 th? year, more than twice th 58.20 allowed last year. A. appropriation of 610 th year for Public Health was no made last year. The complete itemized fina cial statement as compiled L Mr. Smith will appear in ne weeks issue of the Times Vi

document.text: A resolution asking that a soil survey be made of thi county was passed by thi Board of Supervisors at the re. ular monthly meeting Wednes day morning at 10 oclock. R. B- Hudgins appeared bi f o r e the meeting explainin. that a certain number of eoui ties will begiven a soil surve next year by the state and Fee enal government, at no cost tc the county and asking the sup ervisors to aid in obtaining th survey for Appomattox county The matter of making an ap propriation for the eradicatioi of tuberculosis among cattle held over from the last meet ing, was voted against becaus-. of a lack of funds at the pret ent time. Claude W. Smith, count clerk, reported that the stat had offered to allow the court ty 125 in service on its weigh and measures equipment, ant the board agreed to thes terms. Testing of gas pumpt scales, a n d measures will b given in exchange. A resolution was adopted a the request of the Prince Ed ward County board agreeing to co-operate with agencie and governing bodies to inter est the state highway commis sion in the construction of a road from Farmville to Ameli Court House, which woulo shorten the distance betweex the tw o fourteen to eighteei miles by cutting off Burkeviile A bill for forest fire protec tion of 62.02 was allowe. and also, the following ac counts judges salary, 315,- 99 R. L. Burke, d o g license tags and receipt cards, 55-80 expenses of treasurers office, filing cabinet, postage, tax tic kets, etc, 328 Lunacy com mission, 17.40 Virignia code 28. Thfi usual pauper claim were allowed. The allowanc of George Booker was raise from 2 to 5.

document.text: VIRGINIA In the Clerks Office of the Cir cuit Court of Appomattox County, on the 13th day of July, 1961. Edna M. Crelia, Plaintiff Against Virginia R. Lawson, 1 Dutch J. Leffel, Clauddne Gharndcki, Virginia Firkal, Esterieen Blankenship, Helen L Pouker, Malcolm L. Leffel, Bud Herman Rogers, Shirman Edward Rog ers, and others, and Shirman Edward Rogers, if living, or if he be dead, then the widow and heirs, devisees and successors in title, and others, parties defen dant by the general description of parties unknown. The object of this suit is to have partition of the real estate of which the late Claude E. Leffel died seized, containing 299.17 acres a- bout five miles northeast of Ever green, Virginia, on Rough Creek. And i t appearing by affidavit fil ed that Virginia R. Lawson, Dutch J Leffel, Claudine Chadnicki, Vir ginia Firkal, Esterieen Blanken ship, Helen L. Pouker, Malcolm L. Leffel, Bud Herman Rogers and Shirman Edward Rogers or if he be dead, the widow and heirs, de visees and successors in title of Shirman Edward Rogers, who are made parties defendant by the gen eral description of parties un known, are not residents of Vir ginia, or their residence is un known,-they are hereby required to appear within ten days after the due publication of this order and do what is necessary to protect their interests. Teste C. W. Smith, Clerk. George Abbitt, Jr., p. q. Appomattox, Virginia. 7-20-4tc

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Johns, Isaac Adams, Andrew B. Baker, John W. Gilliam, Geo. W. Ab bitt, Van Gilliam, Wm. Statham, L. E. Smith, H. C. Babcock, E. R. Abbott and J. H. OBrien. COUNTY TREASURERSWm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. STATE SENATORSThe County has furnished the fol lowing State SenatorsCol. Wyatt Elliott, Col. Samuel D. Mc Dearmon, Col. Robt. B. Poore, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson and Chas. T. Moses. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.

document.text: honor of Mrs Driscoll and Mrs. J. Cullen of Roanoke, and Miss Jean Howerton of Lynch burg. One of the most inter esting features of entertain ment was Miss Davidaons crack shooting. The only thing she sees wrong about the war was that she wasnt sent over seas to get at a Huh occasional ly- Mr. and Mrs. H P. Taylor and H. P., jr., of Lynchburg Mrs. Foster, Mrs Smith, Mrs. T. Hancock and Clerk Claude Smith of Appomattox Mrs. I. V. Driscoll of Roanoke, were guests of Mrs. W. B. Caldwell on Sunday. Miss M a r y Davidson of Lynchburg, is at home for the summer with her father, Mr. J. M. Davidson. Wonder what the many travelers from good road sec tions thought of the Appomat tox roads on July 4, as they oame to t h e neighborhood from all sections? , I guess they thought those who hau died the road business in this county knew their badness. Mr. Lambdon Dawson, of Chester, S. 0., is the guests of his daughter, Mrs Eugene Chick, of this place. We are sorry to hear of the sad death of one of Ms. Emmit Carsons little children and the serious illness of others in his family. Mr. James P Patteson, of Chicago is expected in the neighborhood soon. W t Mr. and Mrs. Ed Ferguson are the happy pasoniv. Its a son. Mr. and Mrs. Harry Alvis and two daughters and Mr. and Mrs. Noel, of Lynchburg, were guests of Mr. and Mrs. Dave Alvis on Sunday. Mr. and Mrs.EamesStKaton, Wih t t h e   a d e   k   g  Clark, were1 week-end guests of Mr. H. B. Jennings. Mi s s Jean Howerton, of Lynchburg, Was the week-end guest of Mrs. Samuel Davidson. The farmers of this section uave at last gotten above grass, and crops are looking fine. 1 wish such could be said of the roads. The revival services which are in progress at the Concord Baptist church are increasing in interest and are being large ly attended every night. Tbe meetings will be continued through this week and both day and night services will be held by Rev. N L Loflio, who is conducting them.
